etymology.description: 戈(戈) (gē, "blade") + 止(止) (zhǐ, "foot; to walk") = army going on an expedition -> displays strength
etymology.interpretation: The character 武(wǔ) combines 戈(戈) (gē, "blade") representing weaponry and 止(止) (zhǐ, "foot; to walk") indicating movement or marching, to symbolize the movement of an armed force or military expedition, hence conveying the notion of martial strength.

examples.chinese: 战士依靠武(𠬜)，筑起长城防线(築起長城防線)。
examples.pinyin: Zhànshì yīkào wǔ(𠬜), zhùqǐ chángchéng fángxiàn.
examples.english: The soldier relies on martial strength to build a protective wall.

examples.chinese: 古时将领以武(𠬜)守国(古時將領以武(𠬜)守國)，将敌人拒于门外(將敵人拒於門外)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔshí jiānglǐng yǐ wǔ(𠬜) shǒuguó, jiāng dírén jù yú ménwài.
examples.english: In ancient times, generals defended the country with martial might, keeping enemies at bay.

examples.chinese: 边塞隐约传来武(𠬜)之气势(邊塞隱約傳來武(𠬜)之氣勢)。
examples.pinyin: Biānsài yǐnyuē chuán lái wǔ(𠬜) zhī qìshì.
examples.english: At the frontier, the aura of martial strength can be faintly felt.
